cards.name: Nightshade Schemers
cards.text:
Flying
Kinship — At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Nightshade Schemers, you may reveal it. If you do, each opponent loses 2 life.

rulings.text: Kinship is an ability word that indicates a group of similar triggered abilities that appear on _Morningtide_ creatures. It doesn't have any special rules associated with it.
The first two sentences of every kinship ability are the same (except for the creature's name). Only the last sentence varies from one kinship ability to the next.
You don't have to reveal the top card of your library, even if it shares a creature type with the creature that has the kinship ability.
After the kinship ability finishes resolving, the card you looked at remains on top of your library.

If you have multiple creatures with kinship abilities, each triggers and resolves separately. You'll look at the same card for each one, unless you have some method of shuffling your library or moving that card to a different zone.
If the top card of your library is already revealed (due to Magus of the Future, for example), you still have the option to reveal it or not as part of a kinship ability's effect.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Kinship At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Nightshade Schemers, you may reveal it. If you do, each opponent loses 2 life.

cards.name: Noggin Whack
cards.text:
Prowl {1}{B} (You may cast this for its prowl cost if you dealt combat damage to a player this turn with a Rogue.)
Target player reveals three cards from their hand. You choose two of them. That player discards those cards.

rulings.text: If the player has fewer than three cards in their hand, the player reveals all of them, you choose all of them, and they're all discarded.

cards.originalText:
Prowl {1}{B} (You may play this for its prowl cost if you dealt combat damage to a player this turn with a Rogue.)
Target player reveals three cards from his or her hand. You choose two of them. That player discards those cards.

cards.name: Offalsnout
cards.text:
Flash
When Offalsnout leaves the battlefield, exile target card from a graveyard.
Evoke {B} (You may cast this spell for its evoke cost. If you do, it's sacrificed when it enters the battlefield.)

rulings.text: Evoke doesn't change the timing of when you can cast the creature that has it. If you could cast that creature spell only when you could cast a sorcery, the same is true for cast it with evoke.

If a creature spell cast with evoke changes controllers before it enters the battlefield, it will still be sacrificed when it enters the battlefield. Similarly, if a creature cast with evoke changes controllers after it enters the battlefield but before its sacrifice ability resolves, it will still be sacrificed. In both cases, the controller of the creature at the time it left the battlefield will control its leaves-the-battlefield ability.
When you cast a spell by paying its evoke cost, its mana cost doesn't change. You just pay the evoke cost instead.

Effects that cause you to pay more or less to cast a spell will cause you to pay that much more or less while casting it for its evoke cost, too. That's because they affect the total cost of the spell, not its mana cost.

Whether evoke's sacrifice ability triggers when the creature enters the battlefield depends on whether the spell's controller chose to pay the evoke cost, not whether they actually paid it (if it was reduced or otherwise altered by another ability, for example).
If you're casting a spell "without paying its mana cost," you can't use its evoke ability.

cards.originalText:
Flash
When Offalsnout leaves play, remove target card in a graveyard from the game.
Evoke {B} (You may play this spell for its evoke cost. If you do, it's sacrificed when it comes into play.)

cards.name: Oona's Blackguard
cards.text:
Flying
Each other Rogue creature you control enters the battlefield with an additional +1/+1 counter on it.
Whenever a creature you control with a +1/+1 counter on it deals combat damage to a player, that player discards a card.

rulings.text: If a Rogue would normally enter the battlefield with a certain number of +1/+1 counters on it, it enters the battlefield with that many +1/+1 counters plus one on it instead. If a Rogue would normally enter the battlefield with no +1/+1 counters on it, it enters the battlefield with one +1/+1 counter on it instead.

The creature gets the counter if it would enter the battlefield under your control. It doesn't matter who owns the creature or what zone it enters the battlefield from (such as your opponent's graveyard, for example).

The effects from more than one of these cards are cumulative. That is, if you have two Oona's Blackguard on the battlefield, Rogue creatures you control enter the battlefield with two additional +1/+1 counters on them.
If Oona's Blackguard enters the battlefield at the same time as another Rogue (due to Living End, for example), that creature doesn't get a +1/+1 counter.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Each other Rogue creature you control comes into play with an additional +1/+1 counter on it.
Whenever a creature you control with a +1/+1 counter on it deals combat damage to a player, that player discards a card.

cards.name: Pack's Disdain
cards.text: Choose a creature type. Target creature gets -1/-1 until end of turn for each permanent of the chosen type you control.
cards.flavor: Like the sun to a flower, the adoring gaze of the tribe is sustenance to an elf. To be shunned is to wither.

rulings.text: Note that this spell counts the number of permanents you control of the chosen type, not just the number of creatures you control. It will also take your tribal permanents into account.
You choose a target for this spell as you cast it, but you don't choose a creature type until the spell resolves.

cards.originalText: Choose a creature type. Target creature gets -1/-1 until end of turn for each permanent of the chosen type you control.

cards.name: Prickly Boggart
cards.text: Fear (This creature can't be blocked except by artifact creatures and/or black creatures.)
cards.flavor:
"Even without the spines, who would dare to touch it?"
—Desmera, perfect of Wren's Run

foreignNames.name: トゲだらけのボガート

cards.originalText: Fear

cards.name: Pulling Teeth
cards.text: Clash with an opponent. If you win, target player discards two cards. Otherwise, that player discards a card. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of their library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if their card had a higher converted mana cost.)

rulings.text: The opponent you clash with doesn't have to be the player targeted by Pulling Teeth.

cards.originalText: Clash with an opponent. If you win, target player discards two cards. Otherwise, that player discards a card. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of his or her library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if his or her card had a higher converted mana cost.)

cards.name: Revive the Fallen
cards.text: Return target creature card from a graveyard to its owner's hand. Clash with an opponent. If you win, return Revive the Fallen to its owner's hand. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of their library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if their card had a higher converted mana cost.)

rulings.text: If you win the clash, the spell moves from the stack to your hand as part of its resolution. It never hits the graveyard. If you don't win the clash, the spell is put into the graveyard from the stack as normal.

If the spell is countered or doesn't resolve for any reason (for example, if all its targets become illegal), none of its effects happen. There is no clash, and the spell card won't be returned to your hand.

cards.originalText: Return target creature card in a graveyard to its owner's hand. Clash with an opponent. If you win, return Revive the Fallen to its owner's hand. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of his or her library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if his or her card had a higher converted mana cost.)

cards.name: Scarblade Elite
cards.text: {T}, Exile an Assassin card from your graveyard: Destroy target creature.
cards.flavor: "Rejoice, eyeblight. In your last hours above the earth, those who bury you will finally make you beautiful."
cards.originalText: {T}, Remove an Assassin card in your graveyard from the game: Destroy target creature.

cards.name: Squeaking Pie Grubfellows
cards.text: Kinship — At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Squeaking Pie Grubfellows, you may reveal it. If you do, each opponent discards a card.

rulings.text: Kinship is an ability word that indicates a group of similar triggered abilities that appear on _Morningtide_ creatures. It doesn't have any special rules associated with it.
The first two sentences of every kinship ability are the same (except for the creature's name). Only the last sentence varies from one kinship ability to the next.
You don't have to reveal the top card of your library, even if it shares a creature type with the creature that has the kinship ability.
After the kinship ability finishes resolving, the card you looked at remains on top of your library.

If you have multiple creatures with kinship abilities, each triggers and resolves separately. You'll look at the same card for each one, unless you have some method of shuffling your library or moving that card to a different zone.
If the top card of your library is already revealed (due to Magus of the Future, for example), you still have the option to reveal it or not as part of a kinship ability's effect.

foreignNames.name: チューパイの芋虫仲間

cards.originalText: Kinship At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Squeaking Pie Grubfellows, you may reveal it. If you do, each opponent discards a card.

cards.name: Stenchskipper
cards.text:
Flying
At the beginning of the end step, if you control no Goblins, sacrifice Stenchskipper.
cards.flavor:
"Many believe it to be the manifestation of all that is vile about the boggarts. I believe it should be avoided—from upwind, if possible."
—Cenn Deagan

rulings.text: This ability checks whether you control any Goblins twice each turn: once when the ability would trigger, and once when it resolves. If you control any Goblins at either time, you won't sacrifice Stenchskipper. (If you control any Goblins at the time the ability would trigger, it doesn't trigger at all.)

cards.originalText:
Flying
At end of turn, if you control no Goblins, sacrifice Stenchskipper.

cards.name: Stinkdrinker Bandit
cards.text:
Prowl {1}{B} (You may cast this for its prowl cost if you dealt combat damage to a player this turn with a Goblin or Rogue.)
Whenever a Rogue you control attacks and isn't blocked, it gets +2/+1 until end of turn.

rulings.text: This ability triggers after blockers are declared during the declare blockers step. Each attacking Rogue you control gets +2/+1 if no creatures were assigned to block it. That creature will get the bonus even if an effect causes it to become blocked.

An ability that triggers when something "attacks and isn't blocked" triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.originalText:
Prowl {1}{B} (You may play this for its prowl cost if you dealt combat damage to a player this turn with a Goblin or Rogue.)
Whenever a Rogue you control attacks and isn't blocked, it gets +2/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Violet Pall
cards.text: Destroy target nonblack creature. Create a 1/1 black Faerie Rogue creature token with flying.
cards.flavor: A faerie is the offspring of Oona and mischief.

rulings.text: You get the token, not the player who controlled the creature.

cards.originalText: Destroy target nonblack creature. Put a 1/1 black Faerie Rogue creature token with flying into play.

cards.name: Warren Weirding
cards.text: Target player sacrifices a creature. If a Goblin is sacrificed this way, that player creates two 1/1 black Goblin Rogue creature tokens, and those tokens gain haste until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"And that's when it was discovered that boggarts have just half a brain."
—The Book of Other Folk
cards.originalText: Target player sacrifices a creature. If a Goblin is sacrificed this way, that player puts two 1/1 black Goblin Rogue creature tokens into play, and those tokens gain haste until end of turn.

cards.name: Weed-Pruner Poplar
cards.text: At the beginning of your upkeep, target creature other than Weed-Pruner Poplar gets -1/-1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"When Byoog reached down to pull up a bit of root for the stew, he didn't expect the root to pull back."
—A tale of Auntie Wort

rulings.text: The ability is mandatory. If you're the only player who controls any other creatures, you must target one of your own creatures with the ability.

cards.originalText: At the beginning of your upkeep, target creature other than Weed-Pruner Poplar gets -1/-1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Weirding Shaman
cards.text: {3}{B}, Sacrifice a Goblin: Create two 1/1 black Goblin Rogue creature tokens.
cards.flavor: All boggarts have an auntie, but they don't all have a mum.

foreignNames.name: 運命支配のシャーマン

cards.originalText: {3}{B}, Sacrifice a Goblin: Put two 1/1 black Goblin Rogue creature tokens into play.

cards.name: Boldwyr Heavyweights
cards.text:
Trample
When Boldwyr Heavyweights enters the battlefield, each opponent may search their library for a creature card and put it onto the battlefield. Then each player who searched their library this way shuffles it.
cards.flavor: Even if giants bring nothing else on a journey, they bring attention.

rulings.text: A player who doesn't want to shuffle their library may choose not to search for a creature card.

foreignNames.name: ボールドウィアの重量級

cards.originalText:
Trample
When Boldwyr Heavyweights comes into play, each opponent may search his or her library for a creature card and put it into play. Then each player who searched his or her library this way shuffles it.

cards.name: Boldwyr Intimidator
cards.text:
Cowards can't block Warriors.
{R}: Target creature becomes a Coward until end of turn.
{2}{R}: Target creature becomes a Warrior until end of turn.
cards.flavor: "Now everyone knows what you are."

rulings.text: Coward is a new creature type.
Each of the activated abilities replaces all creature types the affected creature may have had.
Note that the exact wording of this card has changed since it was printed in the _Future Sight_(TM) set, but its functionality is the same.

foreignNames.name: ボールドウィアの威嚇者

cards.originalText:
Cowards can't block Warriors.
{R}: Target creature becomes a Coward until end of turn.
{2}{R}: Target creature becomes a Warrior until end of turn.

cards.name: Borderland Behemoth
cards.text:
Trample
Borderland Behemoth gets +4/+4 for each other Giant you control.
cards.flavor: Giants share nothing but their fury.
cards.originalText:
Trample
Borderland Behemoth gets +4/+4 for each other Giant you control.

cards.name: Brighthearth Banneret
cards.text:
Elemental spells and Warrior spells you cast cost {1} less to cast.
Reinforce 1—{1}{R} ({1}{R}, Discard this card: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.)
cards.flavor: The banner symbolizes the goodwill of the Brighthearth. Their emissaries bring the mastery of fire to other races.

rulings.text: A spell you cast that's both creature types costs {1} less to cast, not {2} less.

The effect reduces the total cost of the spell, regardless of whether you chose to pay additional or alternative costs. For example, if you cast a Rogue spell by paying its prowl cost, Frogtosser Banneret causes that spell to cost {1} less.
When you cast an Elemental spell by paying its evoke cost, this effect reduces the cost to cast that spell by {1}.

foreignNames.name: ブライトハースの旗騎士

cards.originalText:
Elemental spells and Warrior spells you play cost {1} less to play.
Reinforce 1—{1}{R} ({1}{R}, Discard this card: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.)

cards.name: Countryside Crusher
cards.text:
At the beginning of your upkeep, reveal the top card of your library. If it's a land card, put it into your graveyard and repeat this process.
Whenever a land card is put into your graveyard from anywhere, put a +1/+1 counter on Countryside Crusher.

rulings.text: The first ability will keep putting cards from the top of your library into your graveyard until you reveal a nonland card. That nonland card remains on top of your library.

Each time you put a land card into your graveyard with the first ability, the second ability will trigger. Those triggers wait to be put onto the stack until the first ability has completely finished resolving.

cards.originalText:
At the beginning of your upkeep, reveal the top card of your library. If it's a land card, put it into your graveyard and repeat this process.
Whenever a land card is put into your graveyard from anywhere, put a +1/+1 counter on Countryside Crusher.

cards.name: Fire Juggler
cards.text: Whenever Fire Juggler becomes blocked, clash with an opponent. If you win, Fire Juggler deals 4 damage to each creature blocking it. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of their library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if their card had a higher converted mana cost.)
cards.originalText: Whenever Fire Juggler becomes blocked, clash with an opponent. If you win, Fire Juggler deals 4 damage to each creature blocking it. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of his or her library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if his or her card had a higher converted mana cost.)

cards.name: Hostile Realm
cards.text:
Enchant land
Enchanted land has "{T}: Target creature can't block this turn."
cards.flavor: Lorwyn's crust explodes with power when the greater elementals are born. The flamekin use the fallout as cover for forays into enemy territory.
cards.originalText:
Enchant land
Enchanted land has "{T}: Target creature can't block this turn."

cards.name: Kindled Fury
cards.text: Target creature gets +1/+0 and gains first strike until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"All beings carry the fire inside them. The challenge is to unleash it before they dwindle into oblivion."
—Illulia, flamekin soulstoke

rulings.text: Giving a creature first strike after creatures with first strike deal combat damage doesn't prevent that creature from dealing combat damage.

cards.originalText: Target creature gets +1/+0 and gains first strike until end of turn.

cards.name: Lightning Crafter
cards.text:
Champion a Goblin or Shaman (When this enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless you exile another Goblin or Shaman you control. When this leaves the battlefield, that card returns to the battlefield.)
{T}: Lightning Crafter deals 3 damage to any target.
cards.originalText:
Champion a Goblin or Shaman (When this comes into play, sacrifice it unless you remove another Goblin or Shaman you control from the game. When this leaves play, that card returns to play.)
{T}: Lightning Crafter deals 3 damage to target creature or player.

cards.name: Lunk Errant
cards.text: Whenever Lunk Errant attacks alone, it gets +1/+1 and gains trample until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"One's plenty," observed the merrow.
"Way too plenty," agreed the boggart.

rulings.text: Lunk Errant "attacks alone" if it's the only creature declared as an attacker as the declare attackers step begins. The ability won't trigger if Lunk Errant and some other creatures are declared as attackers, then those other creatures leave the battlefield or are otherwise removed from combat. The ability also won't trigger if Lunk Errant is put onto the battlefield attacking, even if no other creatures are attacking at that time.
In a Two-Headed Giant game, Lunk Errant must be the only creature declared as an attacker by the entire attacking team for it to be considered "attacking alone."

cards.originalText: Whenever Lunk Errant attacks alone, it gets +1/+1 and gains trample until end of turn.

cards.text: Kinship — At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Mudbutton Clanger, you may reveal it. If you do, Mudbutton Clanger gets +1/+1 until end of turn.

rulings.text: Kinship is an ability word that indicates a group of similar triggered abilities that appear on _Morningtide_ creatures. It doesn't have any special rules associated with it.

If you have multiple creatures with kinship abilities, each triggers and resolves separately. You'll look at the same card for each one, unless you have some method of shuffling your library or moving that card to a different zone.
If the top card of your library is already revealed (due to Magus of the Future, for example), you still have the option to reveal it or not as part of a kinship ability's effect.

cards.originalText: Kinship At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Mudbutton Clanger, you may reveal it. If you do, Mudbutton Clanger gets +1/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Pyroclast Consul
cards.text: Kinship — At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Pyroclast Consul, you may reveal it. If you do, Pyroclast Consul deals 2 damage to each creature.

rulings.text: Kinship is an ability word that indicates a group of similar triggered abilities that appear on _Morningtide_ creatures. It doesn't have any special rules associated with it.
The first two sentences of every kinship ability are the same (except for the creature's name). Only the last sentence varies from one kinship ability to the next.

If the top card of your library is already revealed (due to Magus of the Future, for example), you still have the option to reveal it or not as part of a kinship ability's effect.

cards.originalText: Kinship At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Pyroclast Consul, you may reveal it. If you do, Pyroclast Consul deals 2 damage to each creature.

cards.name: Rage Forger
cards.text:
When Rage Forger enters the battlefield, put a +1/+1 counter on each other Shaman creature you control.
Whenever a creature you control with a +1/+1 counter on it attacks, you may have that creature deal 1 damage to target player or planeswalker.
cards.originalText:
When Rage Forger comes into play, put a +1/+1 counter on each other Shaman creature you control.
Whenever a creature you control with a +1/+1 counter on it attacks, you may have that creature deal 1 damage to target player.

cards.name: Release the Ants
cards.text: Release the Ants deals 1 damage to any target. Clash with an opponent. If you win, return Release the Ants to its owner's hand. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of their library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if their card had a higher converted mana cost.)

rulings.text: If you win the clash, the spell moves from the stack to your hand as part of its resolution. It never hits the graveyard. If you don't win the clash, the spell is put into the graveyard from the stack as normal.

If the spell is countered or doesn't resolve for any reason (for example, if all its targets become illegal), none of its effects happen. There is no clash, and the spell card won't be returned to your hand.

cards.originalText: Release the Ants deals 1 damage to target creature or player. Clash with an opponent. If you win, return Release the Ants to its owner's hand. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of his or her library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if his or her card had a higher converted mana cost.)

cards.name: Rivals' Duel
cards.text: Choose two target creatures that share no creature types. Those creatures fight each other. (Each deals damage equal to its power to the other.)
cards.flavor: They could agree on one thing only: one of them must die.

rulings.text: The two creatures may be controlled by the same player.

If either one of the creatures leaves the battlefield before Rivals' Duel resolves, no damage is dealt to or by the remaining creature. If both creatures leave the battlefield before Rivals' Duel resolves, the spell doesn't resolve for having no legal targets.
If, by the time Rivals' Duel resolves, an effect has caused the two target creatures to share a creature type, Rivals' Duel doesn't resolve for having no legal targets.

foreignNames.name: ライバル同士の一騎打ち

cards.originalText: Choose two target creatures that share no creature types. Each of those creatures deals damage equal to its power to the other.

cards.name: Roar of the Crowd
cards.text: Choose a creature type. Roar of the Crowd deals damage to any target equal to the number of permanents you control of the chosen type.
cards.flavor: One voice is but a pebble to the rest of the world. A thousand voices at once is an avalanche.

rulings.text: Note that this spell counts the number of permanents you control of the chosen type, not just the number of creatures you control. It will also take your tribal permanents into account.
You choose a target for this spell as you cast it, but you don't choose a creature type until the spell resolves.
Spells and abilities that prevent damage or regenerate the targeted creature must be cast or activated before the creature type is chosen.

cards.originalText: Choose a creature type. Roar of the Crowd deals damage to target creature or player equal to the number of permanents you control of the chosen type.

cards.name: Seething Pathblazer
cards.text: Sacrifice an Elemental: Seething Pathblazer gets +2/+0 and gains first strike until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"Flamekin death rites are elaborate and spectacular affairs. Their greatest fear is death in obscurity."
—Tollek Worldwatcher, journal
cards.originalText: Sacrifice an Elemental: Seething Pathblazer gets +2/+0 and gains first strike until end of turn.

cards.name: Sensation Gorger
cards.text: Kinship — At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Sensation Gorger, you may reveal it. If you do, each player discards their hand, then draws four cards.
cards.flavor: More, more, more!

rulings.text: Kinship is an ability word that indicates a group of similar triggered abilities that appear on _Morningtide_ creatures. It doesn't have any special rules associated with it.
The first two sentences of every kinship ability are the same (except for the creature's name). Only the last sentence varies from one kinship ability to the next.
You don't have to reveal the top card of your library, even if it shares a creature type with the creature that has the kinship ability.
After the kinship ability finishes resolving, the card you looked at remains on top of your library.

If you have multiple creatures with kinship abilities, each triggers and resolves separately. You'll look at the same card for each one, unless you have some method of shuffling your library or moving that card to a different zone.
If the top card of your library is already revealed (due to Magus of the Future, for example), you still have the option to reveal it or not as part of a kinship ability's effect.

cards.originalText: Kinship At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Sensation Gorger, you may reveal it. If you do, each player discards his or her hand and draws four cards.

cards.name: Shard Volley
cards.text:
As an additional cost to cast this spell, sacrifice a land.
Shard Volley deals 3 damage to any target.
cards.flavor: "Let the mountain's teeth pierce our oppressors."
cards.originalText:
As an additional cost to play Shard Volley, sacrifice a land.
Shard Volley deals 3 damage to target creature or player.

cards.name: Shared Animosity
cards.text: Whenever a creature you control attacks, it gets +1/+0 until end of turn for each other attacking creature that shares a creature type with it.
cards.flavor:
"It is the nature of souls that they burn more brightly together than apart."
—Vessifrus, flamekin demagogue

rulings.text: This ability counts creatures, not creature types. For example, if you attack with five creatures — an Elf Shaman, an Elf Warrior, a Goblin Shaman, an Elemental, and a creature with all creature types — the ability will trigger five times. Those creatures will get +3/+0, +2/+0, +2/+0, +1/+0, and +4/+0, respectively.
In a Two-Headed Giant game, only creatures you control trigger the ability and get the bonus, but your teammate's attacking creatures are included in the calculation of those bonuses.

cards.originalText: Whenever a creature you control attacks, it gets +1/+0 until end of turn for each other attacking creature that shares a creature type with it.

cards.name: Spitebellows
cards.text:
When Spitebellows leaves the battlefield, it deals 6 damage to target creature.
Evoke {1}{R}{R} (You may cast this spell for its evoke cost. If you do, it's sacrificed when it enters the battlefield.)
cards.flavor: Disaster stalks with gaping jaws across unready lands.

rulings.text: Evoke doesn't change the timing of when you can cast the creature that has it. If you could cast that creature spell only when you could cast a sorcery, the same is true for cast it with evoke.

If a creature spell cast with evoke changes controllers before it enters the battlefield, it will still be sacrificed when it enters the battlefield. Similarly, if a creature cast with evoke changes controllers after it enters the battlefield but before its sacrifice ability resolves, it will still be sacrificed. In both cases, the controller of the creature at the time it left the battlefield will control its leaves-the-battlefield ability.
When you cast a spell by paying its evoke cost, its mana cost doesn't change. You just pay the evoke cost instead.

Effects that cause you to pay more or less to cast a spell will cause you to pay that much more or less while casting it for its evoke cost, too. That's because they affect the total cost of the spell, not its mana cost.

Whether evoke's sacrifice ability triggers when the creature enters the battlefield depends on whether the spell's controller chose to pay the evoke cost, not whether they actually paid it (if it was reduced or otherwise altered by another ability, for example).
If you're casting a spell "without paying its mana cost," you can't use its evoke ability.

cards.originalText:
When Spitebellows leaves play, it deals 6 damage to target creature.
Evoke {1}{R}{R} (You may play this spell for its evoke cost. If you do, it's sacrificed when it comes into play.)

cards.name: Stingmoggie
cards.text:
Stingmoggie enters the battlefield with two +1/+1 counters on it.
{3}{R}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Stingmoggie: Destroy target artifact or land.
cards.flavor: A path vexed by the stingmoggie was probably the wrong path anyhow.
cards.originalText:
Stingmoggie comes into play with two +1/+1 counters on it.
{3}{R}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Stingmoggie: Destroy target artifact or land.

cards.name: Stomping Slabs
cards.text: Reveal the top seven cards of your library, then put those cards on the bottom of your library in any order. If a card named Stomping Slabs was revealed this way, Stomping Slabs deals 7 damage to any target.

rulings.text: If a card named Stomping Slabs wasn't revealed this way, Stomping Slabs deals no damage to its target.

cards.originalText: Reveal the top seven cards of your library, then put those cards on the bottom of your library in any order. If a card named Stomping Slabs was revealed this way, Stomping Slabs deals 7 damage to target creature or player.

cards.name: Sunflare Shaman
cards.text: {1}{R}, {T}: Sunflare Shaman deals X damage to any target and X damage to itself, where X is the number of Elemental cards in your graveyard.
cards.flavor: A spark to light the guttered heart.

rulings.text: If Sunflare Shaman leaves the battlefield before its ability resolves, it will still deal damage to the target. If Sunflare Shaman is put into your graveyard, it even counts toward the amount of damage dealt.
If the target leaves the battlefield or otherwise becomes an illegal target before the ability resolves, the ability doesn't resolve and Sunflare Shaman won't deal any damage to itself.

foreignNames.name: 太陽弾けのシャーマン

cards.originalText: {1}{R}, {T}: Sunflare Shaman deals X damage to target creature or player and X damage to itself, where X is the number of Elemental cards in your graveyard.

cards.name: Taurean Mauler
cards.text:
Changeling (This card is every creature type.)
Whenever an opponent casts a spell, you may put a +1/+1 counter on Taurean Mauler.
cards.flavor: The power of a waterfall. The fury of an avalanche. The intellect of a gale-force wind.
cards.originalText:
Changeling (This card is every creature type at all times.)
Whenever an opponent plays a spell, you may put a +1/+1 counter on Taurean Mauler.

cards.name: Titan's Revenge
cards.text: Titan's Revenge deals X damage to any target. Clash with an opponent. If you win, return Titan's Revenge to its owner's hand. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of their library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if their card had a higher converted mana cost.)

rulings.text: If you win the clash, the spell moves from the stack to your hand as part of its resolution. It never hits the graveyard. If you don't win the clash, the spell is put into the graveyard from the stack as normal.

If the spell is countered or doesn't resolve for any reason (for example, if all its targets become illegal), none of its effects happen. There is no clash, and the spell card won't be returned to your hand.

cards.originalText: Titan's Revenge deals X damage to target creature or player. Clash with an opponent. If you win, return Titan's Revenge to its owner's hand. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of his or her library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if his or her card had a higher converted mana cost.)

cards.name: Vengeful Firebrand
cards.text:
Vengeful Firebrand has haste as long as a Warrior card is in your graveyard.
{R}: Vengeful Firebrand gets +1/+0 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: The flame of a warrior is never extinguished.
cards.originalText:
Vengeful Firebrand has haste as long as a Warrior card is in your graveyard.
{R}: Vengeful Firebrand gets +1/+0 until end of turn.

cards.name: War-Spike Changeling
cards.text:
Changeling (This card is every creature type.)
{R}: War-Spike Changeling gains first strike until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"Aren't there boggarts enough in Lorwyn? Couldn't it turn into a sheep? Or a sunflower?"
—Olly of Goldmeadow
cards.originalText:
Changeling (This card is every creature type at all times.)
{R}: War-Spike Changeling gains first strike until end of turn.

cards.name: Ambassador Oak
cards.text: When Ambassador Oak enters the battlefield, create a 1/1 green Elf Warrior creature token.
cards.flavor: Treefolk and elves share a common interest in the forests, but really the elves just feel at home with the view from above.
cards.originalText: When Ambassador Oak comes into play, put a 1/1 green Elf Warrior creature token into play.

cards.name: Bosk Banneret
cards.text: Treefolk spells and Shaman spells you cast cost {1} less to cast.
cards.flavor: Deep in a murmuring bosk, where the trees' memories span centuries, the simple banner of green and copper signifies an elder whose rings number more than a faerie's days.

rulings.text: A spell you cast that's both creature types costs {1} less to cast, not {2} less.

The effect reduces the total cost of the spell, regardless of whether you chose to pay additional or alternative costs. For example, if you cast a Rogue spell by paying its prowl cost, Frogtosser Banneret causes that spell to cost {1} less.

cards.originalText: Treefolk spells and Shaman spells you play cost {1} less to play.

cards.name: Bramblewood Paragon
cards.text:
Each other Warrior creature you control enters the battlefield with an additional +1/+1 counter on it.
Each creature you control with a +1/+1 counter on it has trample.
cards.flavor: Those who seek to escape her blades succeed only in dying on their stomachs.

rulings.text: If a Warrior would normally enter the battlefield with a certain number of +1/+1 counters on it, it enters the battlefield with that many +1/+1 counters plus one on it instead. If a Warrior would normally enter the battlefield with no +1/+1 counters on it, it enters the battlefield with one +1/+1 counter on it instead.

The creature gets the counter if it would enter the battlefield under your control. It doesn't matter who owns the creature or what zone it enters the battlefield from (such as your opponent's graveyard, for example).

The effects from more than one Bramblewood Paragon are cumulative. That is, if you have more than one Bramblewood Paragon on the battlefield, Warrior creatures you control enter the battlefield with that many additional +1/+1 counters on them.
If Bramblewood Paragon enters the battlefield at the same time as another Warrior (due to Living End, for example), that creature doesn't get a +1/+1 counter.

cards.originalText:
Each other Warrior creature you control comes into play with an additional +1/+1 counter on it.
Each creature you control with a +1/+1 counter on it has trample.

cards.name: Chameleon Colossus
cards.text:
Changeling (This card is every creature type.)
Protection from black
{2}{G}{G}: Chameleon Colossus gets +X/+X until end of turn, where X is its power.
cards.originalText:
Changeling (This card is every creature type at all times.)
Protection from black
{2}{G}{G}: Chameleon Colossus gets +X/+X until end of turn, where X is its power.

cards.name: Cream of the Crop
cards.text: Whenever a creature enters the battlefield under your control, you may look at the top X cards of your library, where X is that creature's power. If you do, put one of those cards on top of your library and the rest on the bottom of your library in any order.

rulings.text: The creature's power is checked as this ability resolves. If the creature has left the battlefield, use its last known information.
If the creature has 0 power, this ability has no effect.
If the creature has 1 power, this ability lets you look at the top card of your library, then you'll have to leave it there.

cards.originalText: Whenever a creature comes into play under your control, you may look at the top X cards of your library, where X is that creature's power. If you do, put one of those cards on top of your library and the rest on the bottom of your library in any order.

cards.name: Deglamer
cards.text: Choose target artifact or enchantment. Its owner shuffles it into their library.
cards.flavor: The more pleasant an illusion's garb, the more indecent its form laid bare.
cards.originalText: Choose target artifact or enchantment. Its owner shuffles it into his or her library.

cards.name: Earthbrawn
cards.text:
Target creature gets +3/+3 until end of turn.
Reinforce 1—{1}{G} ({1}{G}, Discard this card: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.)
cards.flavor: Gremil finally felt in touch with nature—and felt a need to share the experience with others.
cards.originalText:
Target creature gets +3/+3 until end of turn.
Reinforce 1—{1}{G} ({1}{G}, Discard this card: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.)

cards.name: Elvish Warrior
cards.flavor: As graceful as a deer leaping a stream and as deadly as the wolf waiting in ambush on the other side, elvish warriors are the eyes of the forest as well as its unsheathed claws.

cards.name: Everbark Shaman
cards.text: {T}, Exile a Treefolk card from your graveyard: Search your library for up to two Forest cards and put them onto the battlefield tapped. Then shuffle your library.
cards.flavor: "May you rise again, from seed to sapling to sentience."
cards.originalText: {T}, Remove a Treefolk card in your graveyard from the game: Search your library for two Forest cards and put them into play tapped. Then shuffle your library.

cards.name: Fertilid
cards.text:
Fertilid enters the battlefield with two +1/+1 counters on it.
{1}{G}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Fertilid: Target player searches their library for a basic land card, puts it onto the battlefield tapped, then shuffles their library.

rulings.text: Although the targeted player doesn't need to find a basic land card if they don't want to, that player must shuffle their library.

cards.originalText:
Fertilid comes into play with two +1/+1 counters on it.
{1}{G}, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Fertilid: Target player searches his or her library for a basic land card and puts it into play tapped. Then that player shuffles his or her library.

cards.name: Game-Trail Changeling
cards.text:
Changeling (This card is every creature type.)
Trample
cards.flavor:

—Desmera, perfect of Wren's Run
cards.originalText:
Changeling (This card is every creature type at all times.)
Trample

cards.name: Gilt-Leaf Archdruid
cards.text:
Whenever you cast a Druid spell, you may draw a card.
Tap seven untapped Druids you control: Gain control of all lands target player controls.
cards.flavor: "In our hands, the natural world finds more beauty than nature alone could ever provide."

rulings.text: Since the activated ability doesn't have a tap symbol in its cost, you can tap creatures (including Gilt-Leaf Archdruid itself) that haven't been under your control since your most recent turn began to pay the cost.
The second ability's effect has no duration. You retain control of those lands until the game ends or until some other effect causes them to change control.

cards.originalText:
Whenever you play a Druid spell, you may draw a card.
Tap seven untapped Druids you control: Gain control of all lands target player controls.

cards.name: Greatbow Doyen
cards.text:
Other Archer creatures you control get +1/+1.
Whenever an Archer you control deals damage to a creature, that Archer deals that much damage to that creature's controller.
cards.flavor: "My arrows will ever find you."

rulings.text: The second ability triggers only when an Archer permanent you control deals damage to a creature. It won't trigger when an Archer spell you control deals damage.
The ability will trigger whether the damage is combat damage or not.

cards.originalText:
Other Archer creatures you control get +1/+1.
Whenever an Archer you control deals damage to a creature, that Archer deals that much damage to that creature's controller.

cards.name: Heritage Druid
cards.text: Tap three untapped Elves you control: Add {G}{G}{G}.
cards.flavor:
"Study the great spirits of our age and those of the past. Prune secrets from the branching traceries of our lineage."
—Twila, Gilt-Leaf archdruid

rulings.text: Since Heritage Druid's activated ability doesn't have a tap symbol in its cost, you can tap creatures that haven't been under your control since your most recent turn began (including Heritage Druid itself) to pay the cost.

cards.originalText: Tap three untapped Elves you control: Add {G}{G}{G} to your mana pool.

cards.name: Hunting Triad
cards.text:
Create three 1/1 green Elf Warrior creature tokens.
Reinforce 3—{3}{G} ({3}{G}, Discard this card: Put three +1/+1 counters on target creature.)
cards.flavor: "Eyeblights are easy to track. Just follow the imperfections."
cards.originalText:
Put three 1/1 green Elf Warrior creature tokens into play.
Reinforce 3—{3}{G} ({3}{G}, Discard this card: Put three +1/+1 counters on target creature.)

cards.name: Leaf-Crowned Elder
cards.text: Kinship — At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Leaf-Crowned Elder, you may reveal it. If you do, you may play that card without paying its mana cost.

rulings.text: Kinship is an ability word that indicates a group of similar triggered abilities that appear on _Morningtide_ creatures. It doesn't have any special rules associated with it.
The first two sentences of every kinship ability are the same (except for the creature's name). Only the last sentence varies from one kinship ability to the next.
You don't have to reveal the top card of your library, even if it shares a creature type with the creature that has the kinship ability.
After the kinship ability finishes resolving, the card you looked at remains on top of your library.

If you have multiple creatures with kinship abilities, each triggers and resolves separately. You'll look at the same card for each one, unless you have some method of shuffling your library or moving that card to a different zone.
If the top card of your library is already revealed (due to Magus of the Future, for example), you still have the option to reveal it or not as part of a kinship ability's effect.

You play the revealed card as part of the resolution of this ability. It's played from your library, not your hand. You choose modes, pay additional costs, choose targets, etc. for the card as normal when playing it. Any X in the mana cost will be 0. Alternative costs can't be paid.

cards.originalText: Kinship At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Leaf-Crowned Elder, you may reveal it. If you do, you may play that card without paying its mana cost.

cards.name: Luminescent Rain
cards.text: Choose a creature type. You gain 2 life for each permanent you control of that type.
cards.flavor: Storms in Lorwyn don't patter on village rooftops, but rather drench the clachan in rays of amber light.

rulings.text: Note that this spell counts the number of permanents you control of the chosen type, not just the number of creatures you control. It will also take your tribal permanents into account.

cards.originalText: Choose a creature type. You gain 2 life for each permanent you control of that type.

cards.name: Lys Alana Bowmaster
cards.text:
Reach (This creature can block creatures with flying.)
Whenever you cast an Elf spell, you may have Lys Alana Bowmaster deal 2 damage to target creature with flying.

foreignNames.name: Maestro de arco de Lys Alana
リス・アラナの弓使い

cards.originalText:
Reach (This can block creatures with flying.)
Whenever you play an Elf spell, you may have Lys Alana Bowmaster deal 2 damage to target creature with flying.

cards.name: Orchard Warden
cards.text: Whenever another Treefolk creature enters the battlefield under your control, you may gain life equal to that creature's toughness.
cards.flavor: "After the Rising, a treefolk's mind is as limber and green as its limbs, and is at its most receptive to our teachings."

rulings.text: The creature's toughness is checked as this ability resolves. If the creature has left the battlefield, use its last known information.

cards.originalText: Whenever another Treefolk creature comes into play under your control, you may gain life equal to that creature's toughness.

cards.name: Reach of Branches
cards.text:
Create a 2/5 green Treefolk Shaman creature token.
Whenever a Forest enters the battlefield under your control, you may return Reach of Branches from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavor: Growth has no limits.

rulings.text: The triggered ability will trigger whenever any land with the subtype Forest enters the battlefield under your control, not just one named Forest.
If Reach of Branches leaves your graveyard before its triggered ability resolves, the ability will have no effect, even if the card returns to your graveyard before then.

cards.originalText:
Put a 2/5 green Treefolk Shaman creature token into play.
Whenever a Forest comes into play under your control, you may return Reach of Branches from your graveyard to your hand.

cards.name: Recross the Paths
cards.text: Reveal cards from the top of your library until you reveal a land card. Put that card onto the battlefield and the rest on the bottom of your library in any order. Clash with an opponent. If you win, return Recross the Paths to its owner's hand. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of their library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if their card had a higher converted mana cost.)

rulings.text: If you win the clash, the spell moves from the stack to your hand as part of its resolution. It never hits the graveyard. If you don't win the clash, the spell is put into the graveyard from the stack as normal.

If the spell is countered or doesn't resolve for any reason (for example, if all its targets become illegal), none of its effects happen. There is no clash, and the spell card won't be returned to your hand.
You put the revealed nonland cards on the bottom of your library before you clash.
If you have only nonland cards in your library, you reveal your entire library (one card at a time), rearrange it however you like, and then clash.

cards.originalText: Reveal cards from the top of your library until you reveal a land card. Put that card into play and the rest on the bottom of your library in any order. Clash with an opponent. If you win, return Recross the Paths to its owner's hand. (Each clashing player reveals the top card of his or her library, then puts that card on the top or bottom. A player wins if his or her card had a higher converted mana cost.)

cards.name: Reins of the Vinesteed
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2.
When enchanted creature dies, you may return Reins of the Vinesteed from your graveyard to the battlefield attached to a creature that shares a creature type with that creature.

rulings.text: Reins of the Vinesteed's last ability triggers if it and the creature it's enchanting are both put into the graveyard at the same time, or if the creature it's enchanting is put into the graveyard but Reins of the Vinesteed isn't. (In the second case, Reins of the Vinesteed is then put into the graveyard as a state-based action.)

As the triggered ability resolves, check which creatures on the battlefield have any of the creature types that the previously enchanted creature had as it left the battlefield. If that creature was a Goblin Rogue, for example, Reins of the Vinesteed can be returned to the battlefield attached to either a Goblin creature or a Rogue creature.

This triggered ability doesn't target a creature. You may return Reins of the Vinesteed to the battlefield attached to a creature that has shroud, for example. However, the creature must be able to be legally enchanted by Reins of the Vinesteed. You can't return Reins of the Vinesteed to the battlefield attached to a creature that has protection from green, for example.

You can choose to return Reins of the Vinesteed to the battlefield attached to a creature another player controls. You still control Reins of the Vinesteed. When that creature is put into a graveyard, the ability of Reins of the Vinesteed will trigger again and you'll be able choose another creature for the Aura to enchant.

cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+2.
When enchanted creature is put into a graveyard, you may return Reins of the Vinesteed from your graveyard to play attached to a creature that shares a creature type with that creature.

cards.name: Rhys the Exiled
cards.text:
Whenever Rhys the Exiled attacks, you gain 1 life for each Elf you control.
{B}, Sacrifice an Elf: Regenerate Rhys the Exiled.
cards.flavor: Once a famed hunter and packmaster, now a renegade seeking his own path.

rulings.text: You may sacrifice Rhys the Exiled to pay for its own regeneration ability. However, since Rhys is no longer on the battlefield, the ability will have no effect.

cards.originalText:
Whenever Rhys the Exiled attacks, you gain 1 life for each Elf you control.
{B}, Sacrifice an Elf: Regenerate Rhys the Exiled.

cards.name: Scapeshift
cards.text: Sacrifice any number of lands. Search your library for up to that many land cards, put them onto the battlefield tapped, then shuffle your library.
cards.flavor:
"Changes far greater than the turning of the leaves await us at season's end."
—Colfenor, the Last Yew

rulings.text: You sacrifice the lands as part of the resolution of Scapeshift. It isn't an additional cost. If Scapeshift is countered, you won't sacrifice any lands.

cards.originalText: Sacrifice any number of lands. Search your library for that many land cards, put them into play tapped, then shuffle your library.

cards.name: Unstoppable Ash
cards.text:
Trample
Champion a Treefolk or Warrior (When this enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless you exile another Treefolk or Warrior you control. When this leaves the battlefield, that card returns to the battlefield.)
Whenever a creature you control becomes blocked, it gets +0/+5 until end of turn.
cards.originalText:
Trample
Champion a Treefolk or Warrior (When this comes into play, sacrifice it unless you remove another Treefolk or Warrior you control from the game. When this leaves play, that card returns to play.)
Whenever a creature you control becomes blocked, it gets +0/+5 until end of turn.

cards.name: Walker of the Grove
cards.text:
When Walker of the Grove leaves the battlefield, create a 4/4 green Elemental creature token.
Evoke {4}{G} (You may cast this spell for its evoke cost. If you do, it's sacrificed when it enters the battlefield.)

rulings.text: Evoke doesn't change the timing of when you can cast the creature that has it. If you could cast that creature spell only when you could cast a sorcery, the same is true for cast it with evoke.

If a creature spell cast with evoke changes controllers before it enters the battlefield, it will still be sacrificed when it enters the battlefield. Similarly, if a creature cast with evoke changes controllers after it enters the battlefield but before its sacrifice ability resolves, it will still be sacrificed. In both cases, the controller of the creature at the time it left the battlefield will control its leaves-the-battlefield ability.
When you cast a spell by paying its evoke cost, its mana cost doesn't change. You just pay the evoke cost instead.

Effects that cause you to pay more or less to cast a spell will cause you to pay that much more or less while casting it for its evoke cost, too. That's because they affect the total cost of the spell, not its mana cost.

Whether evoke's sacrifice ability triggers when the creature enters the battlefield depends on whether the spell's controller chose to pay the evoke cost, not whether they actually paid it (if it was reduced or otherwise altered by another ability, for example).
If you're casting a spell "without paying its mana cost," you can't use its evoke ability.

cards.originalText:
When Walker of the Grove leaves play, put a 4/4 green Elemental creature token into play.
Evoke {4}{G} (You may play this spell for its evoke cost. If you do, it's sacrificed when it comes into play.)

cards.name: Winnower Patrol
cards.text: Kinship — At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Winnower Patrol, you may reveal it. If you do, put a +1/+1 counter on Winnower Patrol.

rulings.text: Kinship is an ability word that indicates a group of similar triggered abilities that appear on _Morningtide_ creatures. It doesn't have any special rules associated with it.
The first two sentences of every kinship ability are the same (except for the creature's name). Only the last sentence varies from one kinship ability to the next.
You don't have to reveal the top card of your library, even if it shares a creature type with the creature that has the kinship ability.
After the kinship ability finishes resolving, the card you looked at remains on top of your library.

If you have multiple creatures with kinship abilities, each triggers and resolves separately. You'll look at the same card for each one, unless you have some method of shuffling your library or moving that card to a different zone.
If the top card of your library is already revealed (due to Magus of the Future, for example), you still have the option to reveal it or not as part of a kinship ability's effect.

cards.originalText: Kinship At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Winnower Patrol, you may reveal it. If you do, put a +1/+1 counter on Winnower Patrol.

cards.name: Wolf-Skull Shaman
cards.text: Kinship — At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Wolf-Skull Shaman, you may reveal it. If you do, create a 2/2 green Wolf creature token.
cards.flavor: A chorus of howls answers his call.

rulings.text: Kinship is an ability word that indicates a group of similar triggered abilities that appear on _Morningtide_ creatures. It doesn't have any special rules associated with it.
The first two sentences of every kinship ability are the same (except for the creature's name). Only the last sentence varies from one kinship ability to the next.
You don't have to reveal the top card of your library, even if it shares a creature type with the creature that has the kinship ability.
After the kinship ability finishes resolving, the card you looked at remains on top of your library.

If you have multiple creatures with kinship abilities, each triggers and resolves separately. You'll look at the same card for each one, unless you have some method of shuffling your library or moving that card to a different zone.
If the top card of your library is already revealed (due to Magus of the Future, for example), you still have the option to reveal it or not as part of a kinship ability's effect.

cards.originalText: Kinship At the beginning of your upkeep, you may look at the top card of your library. If it shares a creature type with Wolf-Skull Shaman, you may reveal it. If you do, put a 2/2 green Wolf creature token into play.

cards.name: Cloak and Dagger

rulings.text: Each of these Equipment has two subtypes listed on its type line. The first one is a creature type, which in this case is also a subtype of tribal. The second one is Equipment, which is a subtype of artifact.

Each of these Equipment has a triggered ability that says "Whenever a [creature type] creature enters the battlefield, you may attach [this Equipment] to it." This triggers whenever any creature of the specified creature type enters the battlefield, no matter who controls it. You may attach your Equipment to another player's creature this way, even though you can't do so with the equip ability.

If you attach an Equipment you control to another player's creature, you retain control of the Equipment, but you don't control the creature. Only you can activate the Equipment's equip ability, and if the Equipment's ability triggers again, you choose whether to move the Equipment. Only the creature's controller can activate any activated abilities the Equipment grants to the creature, and "you" in any abilities granted to the creature refers to that player.

cards.name: Diviner's Wand

rulings.text: Each of these Equipment has two subtypes listed on its type line. The first one is a creature type, which in this case is also a subtype of tribal. The second one is Equipment, which is a subtype of artifact.

Each of these Equipment has a triggered ability that says "Whenever a [creature type] creature enters the battlefield, you may attach [this Equipment] to it." This triggers whenever any creature of the specified creature type enters the battlefield, no matter who controls it. You may attach your Equipment to another player's creature this way, even though you can't do so with the equip ability.

If you attach an Equipment you control to another player's creature, you retain control of the Equipment, but you don't control the creature. Only you can activate the Equipment's equip ability, and if the Equipment's ability triggers again, you choose whether to move the Equipment. Only the creature's controller can activate any activated abilities the Equipment grants to the creature, and "you" in any abilities granted to the creature refers to that player.

cards.name: Door of Destinies
cards.text:
As Door of Destinies enters the battlefield, choose a creature type.
Whenever you cast a spell of the chosen type, put a charge counter on Door of Destinies.
Creatures you control of the chosen type get +1/+1 for each charge counter on Door of Destinies.

rulings.text: If you cast a creature spell of the chosen type, Door of Destinies will get a charge counter before the creature enters the battlefield. The creature will enter the battlefield with the additional boost to its power and toughness.

Creature types, such as Human or Sliver, appear after the dash on the type line of creatures. Notably, artifact is not a creature type. A creature may have more than one creature type, such as Goblin Warrior. Such a creature would benefit from Door of Destinies if the chosen creature type was Goblin or Warrior.

cards.originalText:
As Door of Destinies comes into play, choose a creature type.
Whenever you play a spell of that type, put a charge counter on Door of Destinies.
Creatures you control of that type get +1/+1 for each charge counter on Door of Destinies.

cards.name: Obsidian Battle-Axe
cards.flavor: It's the flint that sparks a warrior's rage.

rulings.text: Each of these Equipment has two subtypes listed on its type line. The first one is a creature type, which in this case is also a subtype of tribal. The second one is Equipment, which is a subtype of artifact.

Each of these Equipment has a triggered ability that says "Whenever a [creature type] creature enters the battlefield, you may attach [this Equipment] to it." This triggers whenever any creature of the specified creature type enters the battlefield, no matter who controls it. You may attach your Equipment to another player's creature this way, even though you can't do so with the equip ability.

If you attach an Equipment you control to another player's creature, you retain control of the Equipment, but you don't control the creature. Only you can activate the Equipment's equip ability, and if the Equipment's ability triggers again, you choose whether to move the Equipment. Only the creature's controller can activate any activated abilities the Equipment grants to the creature, and "you" in any abilities granted to the creature refers to that player.

cards.name: Thornbite Staff

rulings.text: Each of these Equipment has two subtypes listed on its type line. The first one is a creature type, which in this case is also a subtype of tribal. The second one is Equipment, which is a subtype of artifact.

Each of these Equipment has a triggered ability that says "Whenever a [creature type] creature enters the battlefield, you may attach [this Equipment] to it." This triggers whenever any creature of the specified creature type enters the battlefield, no matter who controls it. You may attach your Equipment to another player's creature this way, even though you can't do so with the equip ability.

If you attach an Equipment you control to another player's creature, you retain control of the Equipment, but you don't control the creature. Only you can activate the Equipment's equip ability, and if the Equipment's ability triggers again, you choose whether to move the Equipment. Only the creature's controller can activate any activated abilities the Equipment grants to the creature, and "you" in any abilities granted to the creature refers to that player.

cards.name: Veteran's Armaments
Murmuring Bosk
cards.text:
({T}: Add {G}.)
As Murmuring Bosk enters the battlefield, you may reveal a Treefolk card from your hand. If you don't, Murmuring Bosk enters the battlefield tapped.
{T}: Add {W} or {B}. Murmuring Bosk deals 1 damage to you.

rulings.text: Murmuring Bosk is a Forest, but it isn't a basic land. Things that affect basic lands don't affect it. Things that affect basic land types do. For example, you can't find Murmuring Bosk with Fertilid's ability ("searches their library for a basic land card"), but you can find Murmuring Bosk with Everbark Shaman's ability ("search your library for two Forest cards").

cards.originalText:
({T}: Add {G} to your mana pool.)
As Murmuring Bosk comes into play, you may reveal a Treefolk card from your hand. If you don't, Murmuring Bosk comes into play tapped.
{T}: Add {W} or {B} to your mana pool. Murmuring Bosk deals 1 damage to you.

cards.name: Mutavault
cards.text:
{T}: Add {C}.
{1}: Mutavault becomes a 2/2 creature with all creature types until end of turn. It's still a land.
cards.flavor: Some changelings born at Velis Vel never return, but their essence never leaves.

rulings.text: Although Mutavault has all creature types while it's animated, it does not have the changeling keyword ability.

A noncreature permanent that turns into a creature can attack, and its {T} abilities can be activated, only if its controller has continuously controlled that permanent since the beginning of their most recent turn. It doesn't matter how long the permanent has been a creature.
Examples of creature types include Sliver, Goblin, and Soldier. Creature types appear after the dash on the type line of creatures.

cards.originalText:
{T}: Add {1} to your mana pool.
{1}: Mutavault becomes a 2/2 creature with all creature types until end of turn. It's still a land.

cards.name: Primal Beyond
cards.text:
As Primal Beyond enters the battlefield, you may reveal an Elemental card from your hand. If you don't, Primal Beyond enters the battlefield tapped.
{T}: Add {C}.
{T}: Add one mana of any color. Spend this mana only to cast an Elemental spell or activate an ability of an Elemental.

rulings.text: You can use the mana produced by Primal Beyond's last ability to pay an alternative cost (such as evoke) or additional cost incurred while casting an Elemental spell. It's not limited to just that spell's mana cost.
The mana can't be spent to activate activated abilities of Elemental sources that aren't on the battlefield (such as the reinforce ability of an Elemental card in your hand).

cards.originalText:
As Primal Beyond comes into play, you may reveal an Elemental card from your hand. If you don't, Primal Beyond comes into play tapped.
{T}: Add {1} to your mana pool.
{T}: Add one mana of any color to your mana pool. Spend this mana only to play Elemental spells or activated abilities of Elementals.

{T}: Add {W}.
Reinforce 1—{1}{W} ({1}{W}, Discard this card: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.)

cards.name: Afterlife
cards.text: Destroy target creature. It can't be regenerated. Its controller creates a 1/1 white Spirit creature token with flying.
cards.originalText: Destroy target creature. It can't be regenerated. Its controller puts a 1/1 white Spirit creature token with flying into play.

cards.name: Alabaster Wall
cards.text:
Defender (This creature can't attack.)
{T}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn.
cards.flavor: Its mortar is mixed with waters straight from the Fountain of Cho.
cards.originalText:
(Walls can't attack.)
{T}: Prevent the next 1 damage that would be dealt to target creature or player this turn.

cards.name: Armistice
cards.text: {3}{W}{W}: You draw a card and target opponent gains 3 life.
cards.flavor:
We all must profit for peace to last.
—Mercadian saying
cards.originalText: {3}{W}{W}: You draw a card and target opponent gains 3 life.

cards.name: Arrest
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature can't attack or block, and its activated abilities can't be activated.
cards.flavor: Orim had no memory of the previous night—the first thing she could remember was waking up with the dead guard's blood on her hands.

rulings.text: Activated abilities contain a colon. They're generally written "[Cost]: [Effect]." Some keywords are activated abilities and will have colons in their reminder text.

cards.originalText: Enchanted creature can't attack or block, and its activated abilities can't be played.

cards.name: Ballista Squad
cards.text: {X}{W}, {T}: Ballista Squad deals X damage to target attacking or blocking creature.
cards.flavor: The perfect antidote for a tightly packed formation.
cards.originalText: {X}{W}, {T}: Ballista Squad deals X damage to target attacking or blocking creature.

cards.name: Charm Peddler
cards.text: {W}, {T}, Discard a card: The next time a source of your choice would deal damage to target creature this turn, prevent that damage.
cards.originalText: {W}, {T}, Discard a card from your hand: The next time a source of your choice would deal damage to target creature this turn, prevent that damage.

cards.name: Charmed Griffin
cards.text:
Flying
When Charmed Griffin enters the battlefield, each other player may put an artifact or enchantment card onto the battlefield from their hand.
cards.flavor: Are you sure you can afford such a luxury?
cards.originalText:
Flying
When Charmed Griffin comes into play, each other player may put an artifact or enchantment card into play from his or her hand.

cards.name: Cho-Arrim Alchemist
cards.text: {1}{W}{W}, {T}, Discard a card: The next time a source of your choice would deal damage to you this turn, prevent that damage. You gain life equal to the damage prevented this way.
cards.originalText: {1}{W}{W}, {T}, Discard a card from your hand: The next time a source of your choice would deal damage to you this turn, prevent that damage and gain that much life.

cards.name: Cho-Arrim Bruiser
cards.text: Whenever Cho-Arrim Bruiser attacks, you may tap up to two target creatures.
cards.flavor: He doesn't know why the Cho-Arrim fight the Mercadians, but he's happy to bash heads for them anyway.
cards.originalText: Whenever Cho-Arrim Bruiser attacks, you may tap up to two target creatures.

Protection from black
cards.originalText:
Protection from black
If an opponent controls a swamp and you control a plains, you may play Cho-Arrim Legate without paying its mana cost.

cards.name: Cho-Manno, Revolutionary
cards.text: Prevent all damage that would be dealt to Cho-Manno, Revolutionary.
cards.flavor:
"Mercadia's masks can no longer hide the truth. Our day has come at last."
—Cho-Manno
cards.originalText: Prevent all damage that would be dealt to Cho-Manno, Revolutionary.

cards.name: Cho-Manno's Blessing
cards.text:
Flash
Enchant creature
As Cho-Manno's Blessing enters the battlefield, choose a color.
Enchanted creature has protection from the chosen color. This effect doesn't remove Cho-Manno's Blessing.
cards.originalText:
You may play Cho-Manno's Blessing any time you could play an instant.
As Cho-Manno's Blessing comes into play, choose a color.
Enchanted creature has protection from the chosen color. This effect doesn't remove Cho-Manno's Blessing.

cards.name: Common Cause
cards.text: Nonartifact creatures get +2/+2 as long as they all share a color.
cards.flavor: Mercadia City's troops are at their best when they have no enemy to fight.

rulings.text: It really does mean "all creatures", including your opponent's.

The ability gives +2/+2 to all creatures which are not artifact creatures, as long as every one of those creatures is of the same color. They can have additional colors beyond the one they share, but they all have to share one color. If any creature is not of the shared color, the bonus is lost.

cards.originalText: Nonartifact creatures get +2/+2 as long as they all share a color.

cards.name: Cornered Market
cards.text:
Players can't cast spells with the same name as a nontoken permanent.
Players can't play nonbasic lands with the same name as a nontoken permanent.
cards.flavor:
Don't step on the livelihood of other vendors, or they may step on you.
—Mercadian saying

rulings.text: Cornered Market does not prevent effects which put a card onto the battlefield. It only stops people from casting.
This card only looks at permanents, not spells on the stack. So it is possible to cast two instances of a spell onto the stack.

cards.originalText: Players can't play spells or nonbasic lands with the same name as a card in play.

cards.name: Crackdown
cards.text: Nonwhite creatures with power 3 or greater don't untap during their controllers' untap steps.
cards.flavor:
"There is no place for mercy in defense of our lives."
—Ta-Spon, Cho-Arrim executioner
cards.originalText: Nonwhite creatures with power 3 or greater don't untap during their controllers' untap steps.

cards.name: Crossbow Infantry
cards.text: {T}: Crossbow Infantry deals 1 damage to target attacking or blocking creature.
cards.flavor: The crossbow is the ideal weapon for the lazy Mercadians: just point and shoot.
cards.originalText: {T}: Crossbow Infantry deals 1 damage to target attacking or blocking creature.

cards.name: Devout Witness
cards.text: {1}{W}, {T}, Discard a card: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.
cards.flavor: The Cho-Arrim fought Mercadia's decadence with more than just swords.
cards.originalText: {1}{W}, {T}, Discard a card from your hand: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.

cards.name: Disenchant
cards.text: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.
cards.flavor:
The scepter of power is fragile in a calloused hand.
—Cho-Arrim saying

rulings.text: This is not modal. If the target changes from an artifact to an enchantment or vice versa, this still destroys it.

cards.originalText: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.
